title: Analyse der Tag-Struktur in Bibsonomy
subject: ['004 Computer science, internet', '020 Library and information sciences']
description:
In der Studie wird die linguistische Struktur der Tags des frei zugänglichen Tagging-Portals BibSonomy (http://www.bibsonomy.org) untersucht, das von der Universität Kassel betrieben wird.

Für die Analyse der aus unterschiedlichen Zeichenfolgen bestehenden Tag-Daten (samt Nutzungsdaten und Informationen zur jeweils getaggten Quelle) wurde in Ermangelung vorhandener Ansätze ein speziell zugeschnittenes Analyseverfahren entwickelt. Die Tags wurden bezüglich der verwendeten Schriftsätze bereinigt und von etlichen Sonderzeichen befreit. Durch ein sogenanntes Part-of-Speech Tagging wurde die Datenmenge in Subgruppen geteilt und somit ihre Handhabung stark vereinfacht. Innerhalb dieses Analyseschrittes konnten über einen Wörterbuchvergleich und verschiedene Heuristiken die Wortarten und Grundformen von etwa einem Drittel der Tags ermittelt werden. Ein weiteres Drittel bestand aus Zeichenfolgen, die durch bestimmte Trennzeichen aneinandergereiht wurden, während ein letztes Drittel überhaupt nicht zugeordnet werden konnte. Die überwiegende Mehrheit der Tags lag in deutscher oder englischer Sprache vor.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/1/1/BibSo_Ergebnisse_09-07-01.xls', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/1/3/TagAnalyse.pdf', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/1/4/Unknown_ohne_EN_D_WK_7undgroe%C3%9Fer.xls', 'Hänger, Christian and Krätzsch, Christine and Niemann, Christof  (2010) Analyse der Tag-Struktur in Bibsonomy.  [Dataset]']
ubma_additional_title: Tag-Structure Analysis in Bibsonomy
ubma_publications: ["Eckert Kai und Hänger Christian und Niemann Christof (2009), Tagging and Automation - Challenges and Chances for Academic Libraries", "Hänger Christian (2008), Good tags or bad tags? Tagging im Kontext der bibliothekarischen Sacherschließung"]
ubma_project: DFG-Projekt "Collaborative Tagging als neuer Service von Hochschulbibliotheken" | Collaborative Tagging bietet Bibliotheken die Möglichkeit, ihr Wissensmanagement stärker partizipatorisch auszurichten, in dem es die Kundinnen und Kunden an der Erschließung von Medien beteiligt. Die Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim möchte untersuchen, welchen Beitrag Collaborative Tagging für die inhaltliche Erschließung von bisher nicht erschlossenen und daher der Nutzung kaum zugänglichen Dokumenten leisten kann. Im Fokus stehen dabei insbesondere elektronische Dokumente, wie sie z. B. im Rahmen der durch die DFG finanzierten Nationallizenzen in großem Umfang zur Verfügung stehen.

Fragebogen). Nur bei Frage 21 (Nr. 201 im Datensatz) konnte ein Freitext eingegeben werden. title: E-Book-Umfrage an der UB Mannheim 2010 - Fragebogen und Ergebnisdatensatz
subject: 020 Library and information sciences
description:
Die Umfrage wurde mit der Software Limesurvey online mit einer Laufzeit von etwa einem Monat (02.-31.12.2010) durchgeführt und im Weblog der UB, durch Flyer sowie über die Fachreferenten beworben. Als Teilnahmeanreiz wurden außerdem ein E-Book-Reader sowie zwei T-Shirts unter den Umfrageteilnehmern verlost. Die bis dato bekannten Nutzer von Dawsonera wurden per Mail gebeten, sich an der Umfrage zu beteiligen.

Der Fragebogen ist als grafisches Abbild der Online-Eingabemasken der Original-Umfrage hinterlegt. Die Ergebnisdatei besteht in einem csv-Export der in Limesurvey gespeicherten Antworten. In den Spaltenköpfen ist die Nummer der Frage (entsprechend der Zählung im Fragebogen) angegeben, danach ggf. in eckigen Klammern der Text der Antwortoption. Bei Multiple Choice-Fragen wird eine ausgewählte Option in den Daten mit "Ja" wiedergegeben, eine nicht ausgewählte Option mit "Nein". Ansonsten werden die ausgewählten Skalenwerte aufgeführte (vgl. Fragebogen). Nur bei Frage 21 (Nr. 201 im Datensatz) konnte ein Freitext eingegeben werden. Namen und Kontaktdaten, die freiwillig angegeben werden konnten, wurden aus den Ergebnisdaten entfernt.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/2/1/Ebookumfrage.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/2/2/Ebookumfrage_Fragebogen.pdf', 'Kaiser, Jessica and Klein, Annette  (2011) E-Book-Umfrage an der UB Mannheim 2010 - Fragebogen und Ergebnisdatensatz.  [Dataset]']
ubma_additional_title: E-Book Survey at the Mannheim University Library in 2010 - Questionnaire and Results
ubma_publications: Kaiser Jessica und Klein Annette (2011), Die E-Book-Umfrage an der UB Mannheim – Zusammenfassung der Ergebnisse
ubma_project: E-Book-Umfrage 2010 | Im Dezember 2010 führte die UB eine Online-Umfrage zum Thema E-Books durch, um Anregungen für die Weiterentwicklung dieses Angebots insgesamt sowie Rückmeldungen zu der seit einigen Monaten im Test befindlichen Plattform "Dawsonera" zu bekommen, bei der E-Books zunächst "angelesen" und dann für eine elektronische Ausleihe angefragt werden können. Es wurden auch allgemeine Fragen zu Nutzungspräferenzen von elektronischen und gedruckten Büchern gestellt.

In this paper, we investigate the case of supervised matching,where automatically created ontology alignments are verified by an expert. We motivate and describe this use case and its characteristics and discuss why traditional, F-measure based evaluation measures are not suitable to choose the best matching system for this task. Therefore, we investigate several alternative evaluation measures and propose the use of Precision@N curves as a means to assess different matching systems for supervised matching. title: Evaluation measures for ontology matchers in supervised matching scenarios
subject: 004 Computer science, internet
description:
Precision and Recall, as well as their combination in terms of FMeasure,are widely used measures in computer science and generally used to evaluate the overall performance of ontology matchers in fully automatic, unsupervised scenarios. In this paper, we investigate the case of supervised matching,where automatically created ontology alignments are verified by an expert. We motivate and describe this use case and its characteristics and discuss why traditional, F-measure based evaluation measures are not suitable to choose the best matching system for this task. Therefore, we investigate several alternative evaluation measures and propose the use of Precision@N curves as a means to assess different matching systems for supervised matching. We compare the ranking of
ontology matchers from the last OAEI campaign using Precision@N curves to the traditional F-measure based ranking, and discuss means to combine matchers in a way that optimizes the user support in supervised ontology matching.

[Dataset]']
ubma_publications: Ritze Dominique und Paulheim Heiko und Eckert Kai (2013), Evaluation measures for ontology matchers in supervised matching scenarios

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/', '10.7801/28'], 'title': 'Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2012 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten', 'creator': 'Schumm, Irene', 'subject': ['020 Library and information sciences', '650 Management'], 'description': 'Zwischen dem 12.3.2012 und dem 8.4.2012 führte die Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim eine Online-Benutzerumfrage durch. Umfrageteilnehmer konnten an einem Gewinnspiel teilnehmen, bei dem Spirit-T-Shirts und Musik-CDs der Universität Mannheim aus dem Campus-Shop der Universität Mannheim, Eintrittskarten für die Reiss-Engelhorn-Museen, Eintrittskarten für das NATIONALTHEATER MANNHEIM, ein Tablet-PC als Hauptpreis sowie - in drei Zwischenverlosungen - Eintrittskarten für das TECHNOSEUM verlost wurden. Die Umfrage wurde beworben über das Blog und den Newsletter der Universitätsbibliothek, Fakultätsnewsletter, Newsletter an alle Studierende, Plakate, Flyer, Bibliotheksmitarbeiter sowie Quittungsausdrucke der UB. Der Fragebogen ist als PDF-Datei hinterlegt, aus der auch die bedingten Fragen ersichtlich werden. Der Antwortdatensatz ist als csv-Datei hinterlegt und enthält die Daten der 1.802 Teilnehmer, welche die Umfrage vollständig abgeschlossen haben. Vorgegebene, codierte Antworten sind sofort abrufbar. Bei Multiple-Choice-Fragen sind die ausgewählten Optionen mit "Ja" codiert, die nicht ausgewählten Optionen dagegen mit "keine Angabe". Bei kontextabhägen Fragen ist als Antwort stets "NA" hinterlegt, wenn diese dem Teilnehmer nicht angezeigt wurden. Freie Kommentare können dagegen nur eingeschränkt zugänglich gemacht werden, bei Interesse wenden Sie sich bitte an die angegebene Kontaktperson.', 'date': '2013-05-29', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['csv', 'csv', 'text', 'text'], 'language': ['en', 'en', 'en', 'en'], 'rights': ['cc0', 'cc0', 'cc0', 'cc0'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/13/Benutzerumfrage2012KommentareUBMA.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/14/Benutzerumfrage_UBMannheim_2012.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/15/Library_survey_2012_questions.pdf', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/16/Benutzerumfrage_2012_Fragebogen.pdf', 'Schumm, Irene (2013) Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2012 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten. title: Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2012 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten
subject: ['020 Library and information sciences', '650 Management']
description:
Zwischen dem 12.3.2012 und dem 8.4.2012 führte die Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim eine Online-Benutzerumfrage durch. Der Umfragebogen wurde mit Hilfe der Software Limesurvey auf Deutsch und auf Englisch umgesetzt und im Internet frei zugänglich gemacht. Umfrageteilnehmer konnten an einem Gewinnspiel teilnehmen, bei dem Spirit-T-Shirts und Musik-CDs der Universität Mannheim aus dem Campus-Shop der Universität Mannheim, Eintrittskarten für die Reiss-Engelhorn-Museen, Eintrittskarten für das NATIONALTHEATER MANNHEIM, ein Tablet-PC als Hauptpreis sowie - in drei Zwischenverlosungen - Eintrittskarten für das TECHNOSEUM verlost wurden.
Die Umfrage wurde beworben über das Blog und den Newsletter der Universitätsbibliothek, Fakultätsnewsletter, Newsletter an alle Studierende, Plakate, Flyer, Bibliotheksmitarbeiter sowie Quittungsausdrucke der UB.
Der Fragebogen ist als PDF-Datei hinterlegt, aus der auch die bedingten Fragen ersichtlich werden.
Der Antwortdatensatz ist als csv-Datei hinterlegt und enthält die Daten der 1.802 Teilnehmer, welche die Umfrage vollständig abgeschlossen haben. Vorgegebene, codierte Antworten sind sofort abrufbar.
Die gestellten Fragen samt Antwortmöglichkeit sind spaltenweise hinterlegt. In den verschiedenen Zeilen schließlich sind die gegebenen Antworten dokumentiert, die als Skalenwerte vorgegeben waren.
Bei Multiple-Choice-Fragen sind die ausgewählten Optionen mit "Ja" codiert, die nicht ausgewählten Optionen dagegen mit "keine Angabe". Bei kontextabhägen Fragen ist als Antwort stets "NA" hinterlegt, wenn diese dem Teilnehmer nicht angezeigt wurden.
Freie Kommentare können dagegen nur eingeschränkt zugänglich gemacht werden, bei Interesse wenden Sie sich bitte an die angegebene Kontaktperson.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/13/Benutzerumfrage2012KommentareUBMA.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/14/Benutzerumfrage_UBMannheim_2012.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/15/Library_survey_2012_questions.pdf', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/28/16/Benutzerumfrage_2012_Fragebogen.pdf', 'Schumm, Irene  (2013) Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2012 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten.  [Dataset]']
ubma_additional_title: Survey of the Mannheim University Library 2012 - questionnaire and results
ubma_publications: Kaiser Jessica und Klein Annette und Knudsen Per und Leichert Gabriele und Schumm Irene (2012), Umfrage der UB Mannheim - Ergebnisse der Auswertung : "Sagen Sie uns Ihre Meinung" vom 13.3. – 8.4.2012 in Zusammenarbeit mit dem Lehrstuhl für ABWL, Public & Nonprofit Management (Prof. Helmig)

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/48/', '10.7801/48'], 'title': 'Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web of 2012 (aggregated by pay-level-domain)', 'creator': ['Meusel, Robert', 'Lehmberg, Oliver', 'Bizer, Christian'], 'subject': '004 Computer science, internet', 'description': 'Knowledge about the general graph structure of this graph is important for designing ranking methods for search engines. To amend the ranking calculated by search engines for different websites, search engine optimization agencies focus on linkage structure for their clients. An extreme appearance of ranking manipulation manifests in spam networks, where pages and websites publishing dubious content try to increase their ratings by setting a massive number of links to other pages and retrieve backlinks. The WDC Hyperlink Graph aggregated by pay-level-domain has been extracted from the Common Crawl 2012 web corpus and covers 43 million pay-level-domains, linked by 623 million connections which have been derived from hyperlinks between the pages contained in the pay-level-domains.', 'date': '2013-11-12', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['archive', 'archive'], 'language': ['en', 'en'], 'rights': ['no_license', 'no_license'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/48/2/pld-index.gz', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/48/3/pld-arc.gz', 'Meusel, Robert and Lehmberg, Oliver and Bizer, Christian (2013) Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web of 2012 (aggregated by pay-level-domain). [Dataset]'], 'ubma_additional_title': 'Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web (aggregated by pay-level-domain) extracted from the Common Crawl Dataset 2012', 'ubma_availibility': '1', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'Data is available as download. Index File and Arc files. Please see http://webdatacommons.org/hyperlinkgraph for more information.', 'id_number': '10.7801/48', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': ["Meusel Robert und Vigna Sebastiano und Lehmberg Oliver und Bizer Christian (2015), The Graph Structure in the Web - Analyzed on Different Aggregation Levels", "Lehmberg Oliver und Meusel Robert und Bizer Christian (2014), Graph structure in the Web - aggregated by Pay-Level Domain", "Meusel Robert und Vigna Sebastiano und Lehmberg Oliver und Bizer Christian (2014), Graph Structure in the Web - Revisited"], 'ubma_url_external': ['http://webdatacommons.org/hyperlinkgraph/index.html', 'http://webdatacommons.org/hyperlinkgraph/2012-08/topology.html', 'http://webdatacommons.org/hyperlinkgraph/2012-08/download.html'], 'ubma_project': 'Web Data Commons - Hyperlink Graph | Knowledge about the general graph structure of this graph is important for designing ranking methods for search engines. To amend the ranking calculated by search engines for different websites, search engine optimization agencies focus on linkage structure for their clients. An extreme appearance of ranking manipulation manifests in spam networks, where pages and websites publishing dubious content try to increase their ratings by setting a massive number of links to other pages and retrieve backlinks. The WDC Hyperlink Graph has been extracted from the Common Crawl 2012 web corpus and covers 3.5 billion web pages and 128 billion hyperlinks between these pages. To the best of our knowledge, this graph is the largest hyperlink graph that is available to the public outside companies such as Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft.'}
title: Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web of 2012 (aggregated by pay-level-domain)
subject: 004 Computer science, internet
description: Knowledge about the general graph structure of this graph is important for designing ranking methods for search engines. To amend the ranking calculated by search engines for different websites, search engine optimization agencies focus on linkage structure for their clients. An extreme appearance of ranking manipulation manifests in spam networks, where pages and websites publishing dubious content try to increase their ratings by setting a massive number of links to other pages and retrieve backlinks. The WDC Hyperlink Graph aggregated by pay-level-domain has been extracted from the Common Crawl 2012 web corpus and covers 43 million pay-level-domains, linked by 623 million connections which have been derived from hyperlinks between the pages contained in the pay-level-domains.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/48/2/pld-index.gz', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/48/3/pld-arc.gz', 'Meusel, Robert and Lehmberg, Oliver and Bizer, Christian  (2013) Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web of 2012 (aggregated by pay-level-domain).  [Dataset]']
ubma_additional_title: Hyperlink Graph of the World Wide Web (aggregated by pay-level-domain) extracted from the Common Crawl Dataset 2012
ubma_publications: ["Meusel Robert und Vigna Sebastiano und Lehmberg Oliver und Bizer Christian (2015), The Graph Structure in the Web - Analyzed on Different Aggregation Levels", "Lehmberg Oliver und Meusel Robert und Bizer Christian (2014), Graph structure in the Web - aggregated by Pay-Level Domain", "Meusel Robert und Vigna Sebastiano und Lehmberg Oliver und Bizer Christian (2014), Graph Structure in the Web - Revisited"]
ubma_project: Web Data Commons - Hyperlink Graph | Knowledge about the general graph structure of this graph is important for designing ranking methods for search engines. To amend the ranking calculated by search engines for different websites, search engine optimization agencies focus on linkage structure for their clients. An extreme appearance of ranking manipulation manifests in spam networks, where pages and websites publishing dubious content try to increase their ratings by setting a massive number of links to other pages and retrieve backlinks. The WDC Hyperlink Graph has been extracted from the Common Crawl 2012 web corpus and covers 3.5 billion web pages and 128 billion hyperlinks between these pages. To the best of our knowledge, this graph is the largest hyperlink graph that is available to the public outside companies such as Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft.
ubma_availibility_free: Data is available as download. Index File and Arc files. Please see http://webdatacommons.org/hyperlinkgraph for more information.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/60/', '10.7801/60'], 'title': 'Effects of Cultural Intelligence in Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration - Experimental data', 'creator': 'Li, Ye', 'subject': ['150 Psychology', '600 Technology'], 'description': 'People from different countries are increasingly working together with the sup-port of information and communication technologies. Such cross-cultural virtual collaboration is highly challenging due to the geographical separation and cultural diversity among collaborators. This study investigates the effects of an individual capability, cultural intelligence, on cross-cultural virtual collaboration processes in a controlled experiment. Thirty-five cross-cultural virtual dyads were formed and instructed to collaborate in a proposal writing task. Their interaction processes were analyzed with Bales’ Interaction Process Analysis. The results suggest that individuals with higher CQ demonstrated more positive reactions and attempted answers in the cross-cultural virtual collaboration after controlling for foreign language proficiency. The increased amounts of the two categories of interaction acts led to improved peer satisfaction. The study links CQ with proximal behavioral outcomes and identifies CQ as a key individual capability that predicts behaviors and affective outcomes in cross-cultural virtual collaboration.', 'date': '2014-01-23', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'identifier': 'Li, Ye (2014) Effects of Cultural Intelligence in Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration - Experimental data. [Dataset]', 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'Send a request to office-eris(at)uni-mannheim.de', 'id_number': '10.7801/60', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': ["Li Ye und Skulason Asgeir (2013), Uncovering the Effects of Cultural Intelligence on Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration Processes", 'Li Ye und Li Hui und Mädche Alexander und Rau Pei-Luen Patrick (2012), "Are You a Trustworthy Partner in a Cross-cultural Virtual Environment?" – Behavioral Cultural Intelligence and Receptivity-based Trust in Virtual Collaboration']}
title: Effects of Cultural Intelligence in Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration - Experimental data
subject: ['150 Psychology', '600 Technology']
description: People from different countries are increasingly working together with the sup-port of information and communication technologies. Such cross-cultural virtual collaboration is highly challenging due to the geographical separation and cultural diversity among collaborators. This study investigates the effects of an individual capability, cultural intelligence, on cross-cultural virtual collaboration processes in a controlled experiment. Thirty-five cross-cultural virtual dyads were formed and instructed to collaborate in a proposal writing task. Their interaction processes were analyzed with Bales’ Interaction Process Analysis. The results suggest that individuals with higher CQ demonstrated more positive reactions and attempted answers in the cross-cultural virtual collaboration after controlling for foreign language proficiency. The increased amounts of the two categories of interaction acts led to improved peer satisfaction. The study links CQ with proximal behavioral outcomes and identifies CQ as a key individual capability that predicts behaviors and affective outcomes in cross-cultural virtual collaboration.
identifier: Li, Ye  (2014) Effects of Cultural Intelligence in Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration - Experimental data.  [Dataset]
ubma_publications: ["Li Ye und Skulason Asgeir (2013), Uncovering the Effects of Cultural Intelligence on Cross-Cultural Virtual Collaboration Processes", 'Li Ye und Li Hui und Mädche Alexander und Rau Pei-Luen Patrick (2012), "Are You a Trustworthy Partner in a Cross-cultural Virtual Environment?" – Behavioral Cultural Intelligence and Receptivity-based Trust in Virtual Collaboration']
ubma_availibility_free: Send a request to office-eris(at)uni-mannheim.de

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/61/', '10.7801/61'], 'title': 'Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams - Interview transcripts', 'creator': 'Li, Ye', 'subject': ['600 Technology', '650 Management'], 'description': 'Coordination of interdependent tasks across geographical, temporal and socio-cultural boundaries has been identified as a critical antecedent to global software development (GSD) team performance. Since GSD teams are increasingly required to achieve software development agility and respond to changing business requirements, conventional plan-driven software development methods become inadequate to manage the cross-boundary dependencies. To cope with this issue, there is an emerging trend of implementing change-driven agile methods in GSD; we call this practice agile GSD. This paper focuses on the formulation of coordination strategies in agile GSD. We argue that Coordination Theory (CT) can serve as a useful lens to develop a deeper understanding of the formulation process. We present a case study in a leading software development company using agile GSD and present preliminary results by applying the lens of CT.', 'date': '2014-01-23', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'identifier': 'Li, Ye (2014) Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams - Interview transcripts. [Dataset]', 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'Send a request to office-eris(at)uni-mannheim.de', 'id_number': '10.7801/61', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': "Li Ye und Mädche Alexander (2012), Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams"}
title: Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams - Interview transcripts
subject: ['600 Technology', '650 Management']
description: Coordination of interdependent tasks across geographical, temporal and socio-cultural boundaries has been identified as a critical antecedent to global software development (GSD) team performance. Since GSD teams are increasingly required to achieve software development agility and respond to changing business requirements, conventional plan-driven software development methods become inadequate to manage the cross-boundary dependencies. To cope with this issue, there is an emerging trend of implementing change-driven agile methods in GSD; we call this practice agile GSD. This paper focuses on the formulation of coordination strategies in agile GSD. We argue that Coordination Theory (CT) can serve as a useful lens to develop a deeper understanding of the formulation process. We present a case study in a leading software development company using agile GSD and present preliminary results by applying the lens of CT.
identifier: Li, Ye  (2014) Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams - Interview transcripts.  [Dataset]
ubma_publications: Li Ye und Mädche Alexander (2012), Formulating Effective Coordination Strategies in Agile Global Software Development Teams
ubma_availibility_free: Send a request to office-eris(at)uni-mannheim.de

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/68/', '10.7801/68'], 'title': 'Interview Data for the following study: Hadasch, F., Mueller, B., & Maedche, A. (2012). Exploring antecedent environmental and organizational factors to user-caused information leaks: A qualitative study.', 'creator': 'Hadasch, Frank', 'subject': '650 Management', 'description': 'Sensitive company information can leak to unauthorized parties in case employees do not perform effective protective measures while using application systems for their day-to-day tasks. To reduce the risks for such information leakage incidents, many companies require their employees to follow information systems (IS) security policies and promote awareness programs to increase IS security awareness. The design of effective IS security awareness approaches is addressed by existing research. However, understanding how environmental and organizational factors influence organizations individuals’ IS security awareness is limited. Using grounded theory as qualitative research approach we collect empirical data from 22 informants. The interview data of company outsiders and company insiders is analyzed to identify contextual factors and explain associations among them. Our stated propositions help to understand why individuals in one organization are well aware of IS security threats and policies, while another organization’s individuals have a lower level of IS security awareness.', 'date': '2012-09-01', 'type': ['Text', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'archive', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc_by_nc_nd', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/68/2/Hadasch_ea_2012_InterviewData_2014_05_25.zip', 'Hadasch, Frank (2012) Interview Data for the following study: Hadasch, F., Mueller, B., & Maedche, A. (2012). Exploring antecedent environmental and organizational factors to user-caused information leaks: A qualitative study. [Text]'], 'ubma_language': 'ger', 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'id_number': '10.7801/68', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': ["Hadasch Frank und Müller Benjamin und Mädche Alexander (2012), Exploring Antecedent Environmental and Organizational Factors to User-Caused Information Leaks: A Qualitative Study", "Hadasch Frank (2014), Influencing Information Technology Users’ Rule Compliance : Multiple Studies in the Security and Business Process Context"], 'ubma_project': 'USIFES | User-Centric Security Information Flow in Enterprise Systems'}
title: Interview Data for the following study: Hadasch, F., Mueller, B., & Maedche, A. (2012). Exploring antecedent environmental and organizational factors to user-caused information leaks: A qualitative study.
subject: 650 Management
description: Sensitive company information can leak to unauthorized parties in case employees do not perform effective protective measures while using application systems for their day-to-day tasks. To reduce the risks for such information leakage incidents, many companies require their employees to follow information systems (IS) security policies and promote awareness programs to increase IS security awareness. The design of effective IS security awareness approaches is addressed by existing research. However, understanding how environmental and organizational factors influence organizations individuals’ IS security awareness is limited. Using grounded theory as qualitative research approach we collect empirical data from 22 informants. The interview data of company outsiders and company insiders is analyzed to identify contextual factors and explain associations among them. Our stated propositions help to understand why individuals in one organization are well aware of IS security threats and policies, while another organization’s individuals have a lower level of IS security awareness.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/74/', '10.7801/74'], 'title': 'Cross-Functional Integration of Product Management and Product Design in Application Software Development: Exploration of Success Factors - Interview Transcripts', 'creator': ['Meth, Hendrik', 'Kahrau, Felix'], 'subject': ['600 Technology', '620 Engineering', '650 Management'], 'description': 'The industrialization of application software development is a key trend in the software industry. One important element of industrialized development processes is the introduction of a division of work with specialized competencies. Cross-functional integration is a fundamental and well established concept in product development. Its potential has also been recognized in application software development. Many enterprise application software vendors have established product management to complement software development from a business perspective, while R&D primarily focuses on technology aspects. Due to the growing significance of usability and user experience, the product design function has become increasingly important for application software development. However, there is little empirical work concerning cross-functional integration of product management and product design in application software development. The work presented in this paper explores success factors of this cross-functional integration.', 'date': '2011', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'archive', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc_by_nc_nd', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/74/1/2011_CFI_Interview_Transcripts.zip', 'Meth, Hendrik and Kahrau, Felix (2011) Cross-Functional Integration of Product Management and Product Design in Application Software Development: Exploration of Success Factors - Interview Transcripts. [Dataset]'], 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'id_number': '10.7801/74', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': "Botzenhardt Achim und Meth Hendrik und Mädche Alexander (2011), Cross-Functional Integration of Product Management and Product Design in Application Software Development: Exploration of Success Factors"}
title: Cross-Functional Integration of Product Management and Product Design in Application Software Development: Exploration of Success Factors - Interview Transcripts
subject: ['600 Technology', '620 Engineering', '650 Management']
description: The industrialization of application software development is a key trend in the software industry. One important element of industrialized development processes is the introduction of a division of work with specialized competencies. Cross-functional integration is a fundamental and well established concept in product development. Its potential has also been recognized in application software development. Many enterprise application software vendors have established product management to complement software development from a business perspective, while R&D primarily focuses on technology aspects. Due to the growing significance of usability and user experience, the product design function has become increasingly important for application software development. However, there is little empirical work concerning cross-functional integration of product management and product design in application software development. The work presented in this paper explores success factors of this cross-functional integration.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/76/', '10.7801/76'], 'title': 'Form and function - designing successful mobile data services - Survey Data', 'creator': 'Botzenhardt, Achim', 'subject': ['600 Technology', '620 Engineering'], 'description': 'Mobile devices, along with mobile data services (MDS), have become powerful attendants in our daily life. Starting with simple communication services, MDS now offer a solution for almost every demand in private and business life. The market for MDS has become very competitive and is creating pressure on MDS providers with continuously increasing consumer demands. Recently, design has received much attention, since it provides vast opportunities for differentiating offerings and gaining competitive advantage. However, there is often semantic confusion when it comes to the concrete application of design. Based on the theoretical integration of user satisfaction and technology acceptance of Wixom and Todd (2005) and by conceptualizing form and function as the two major components of design, we propose a theoretical model that specifically investigates which MDS design characteristics influence consumers’ perception and behavioral intention. We empirically tested our model with partial least square (PLS) analysis, based on a sample of 2,295 responses from MDS users in the mobile banking context. The findings reveal that both components of design – form and function – were positively associated with satisfaction. The relationship between form and satisfaction was moderated by MDS consumer age and MDS usage frequency.', 'date': '2014', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'other', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc_by_nc_nd', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/76/1/2013_MDS_Survey_Data.sav', 'Botzenhardt, Achim  (2014) Form and function - designing successful mobile data services - Survey Data.  [Dataset]'], 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'Send a request to maedche(at)es.uni-mannheim.de', 'id_number': '10.7801/76', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE'}
title: Form and function - designing successful mobile data services - Survey Data
subject: ['600 Technology', '620 Engineering']
description: Mobile devices, along with mobile data services (MDS), have become powerful attendants in our daily life. Starting with simple communication services, MDS now offer a solution for almost every demand in private and business life. The market for MDS has become very competitive and is creating pressure on MDS providers with continuously increasing consumer demands. Recently, design has received much attention, since it provides vast opportunities for differentiating offerings and gaining competitive advantage. However, there is often semantic confusion when it comes to the concrete application of design. Based on the theoretical integration of user satisfaction and technology acceptance of Wixom and Todd (2005) and by conceptualizing form and function as the two major components of design, we propose a theoretical model that specifically investigates which MDS design characteristics influence consumers’ perception and behavioral intention. We empirically tested our model with partial least square (PLS) analysis, based on a sample of 2,295 responses from MDS users in the mobile banking context. The findings reveal that both components of design – form and function – were positively associated with satisfaction. The relationship between form and satisfaction was moderated by MDS consumer age and MDS usage frequency.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/76/1/2013_MDS_Survey_Data.sav', 'Botzenhardt, Achim  (2014) Form and function - designing successful mobile data services - Survey Data.  [Dataset]']
ubma_availibility_free: Send a request to maedche(at)es.uni-mannheim.de

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/80/', '10.7801/80'], 'title': 'Exploring Principles of User-Centered Agile Software Development: A Literature Review', 'creator': 'Brhel, Manuel', 'subject': ['004 Computer science, internet', '020 Library and information sciences', '650 Management'], 'description': 'Context: Software development has been characterized by two major approaches in the last decade: Agile Software Development aiming at increased velocity and flexibility during the development process and User-Centered Design putting the goals and needs of the system’s end-users in the development focus to deliver software with appropriate usability. Hybrid development models, summarized as User-Centered Agile Software Development (UCASD) in this article, propose to combine the merits of both approaches to design software that is both useful and usable. Objective: This paper aims at capturing the current state of the art in UCASD approaches and deriving generic principles from these approaches. More specifically, we are investigating the following research question: Which principles constitute a user-centered agile software development approach? Method: A systematic review of the literature in UCASD is performed. Identified works are analyzed using a coding scheme that differentiates four integration levels: process, practices, people and technology. Through subsequent synthesis of the identified codes, generic principles of UCASD are derived. Results: We identified and analyzed 83 relevant publications. The analysis resulted in a differentiated coding system and five principles for UCASD: (1) Separate Product Discovery and Product Creation, (2) Iterative and Incremental Design and Development, (3) Parallel Interwoven Creation Tracks, (4) Continuous Stakeholder Involvement, and (5) Artifact-Mediated Communication. Conclusion: Through the results of our paper, we intend to contribute to the Software Development body of knowledge by (1) providing a broad overview of existing works in the area of UCASD, (2) deriving an analysis framework (in form a coding system) for works in this area, going beyond former classifications, and (3) identifying generic principles of UCASD and associating them with specific practices and processes.', 'date': '2014-03-25', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'csv', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc_by_nc_sa', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/80/1/Codebasis%20Komplett.xls', 'Brhel, Manuel (2014) Exploring Principles of User-Centered Agile Software Development: A Literature Review. [Dataset]'], 'ubma_language': 'eng', 'ubma_availibility': '1', 'id_number': '10.7801/80', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': "Brhel Manuel und Meth Hendrik und Maedche Alexander und Werder Karl (2015), Exploring principles of user-centered agile software development: A literature review"}
title: Exploring Principles of User-Centered Agile Software Development: A Literature Review
subject: ['004 Computer science, internet', '020 Library and information sciences', '650 Management']
description: Context: Software development has been characterized by two major approaches in the last decade: Agile Software Development aiming at increased velocity and flexibility during the development process and User-Centered Design putting the goals and needs of the system’s end-users in the development focus to deliver software with appropriate usability. Hybrid development models, summarized as User-Centered Agile Software Development (UCASD) in this article, propose to combine the merits of both approaches to design software that is both useful and usable. Objective: This paper aims at capturing the current state of the art in UCASD approaches and deriving generic principles from these approaches. More specifically, we are investigating the following research question: Which principles constitute a user-centered agile software development approach? Method: A systematic review of the literature in UCASD is performed. Identified works are analyzed using a coding scheme that differentiates four integration levels: process, practices, people and technology. Through subsequent synthesis of the identified codes, generic principles of UCASD are derived. Results: We identified and analyzed 83 relevant publications. The analysis resulted in a differentiated coding system and five principles for UCASD: (1) Separate Product Discovery and Product Creation, (2) Iterative and Incremental Design and Development, (3) Parallel Interwoven Creation Tracks, (4) Continuous Stakeholder Involvement, and (5) Artifact-Mediated Communication. Conclusion: Through the results of our paper, we intend to contribute to the Software Development body of knowledge by (1) providing a broad overview of existing works in the area of UCASD, (2) deriving an analysis framework (in form a coding system) for works in this area, going beyond former classifications, and (3) identifying generic principles of UCASD and associating them with specific practices and processes.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/80/1/Codebasis%20Komplett.xls', 'Brhel, Manuel  (2014) Exploring Principles of User-Centered Agile Software Development: A Literature Review.  [Dataset]']
ubma_publications: Brhel Manuel und Meth Hendrik und Maedche Alexander und Werder Karl (2015), Exploring principles of user-centered agile software development: A literature review

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/87/', '10.7801/87'], 'title': 'Data from the paper: Weakly supervised construction of a repository of iconic images', 'creator': ['Weiland, Lydia', 'Effelsberg, Wolfgang', 'Ponzetto, Simone Paolo'], 'subject': '004 Computer science, internet', 'description': 'We present a first attempt at semi-automatically harvesting a dataset of iconic images. Iconic images are depicting objects or scenes, which arouse associations to abstract topics. Our method starts with representative topic-evoking images from Wikipedia, which are labeled with relevant concepts and entities found in their associated captions. These are used to query an online image repository (i.e., Flickr), in order to further acquire additional examples of topic-specific iconic relations. To this end, we leverage a combination of visual similarity measures, image clustering and matching algorithms to acquire clusters of iconic images that are topically connected to the original seed images, while also allowing for various degrees of diversity. Our first results are promising in that they indicate the feasibility of the task and that we are able to build a first version of our resource with minimal supervision.', 'date': '2014-06', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['text', 'archive'], 'language': ['en', 'en'], 'rights': ['cc_by', 'cc_by'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/87/3/ReadMe.txt', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/87/2/DatasetIconicImages.zip', 'Weiland, Lydia and Effelsberg, Wolfgang and Ponzetto, Simone Paolo (2014) Data from the paper: Weakly supervised construction of a repository of iconic images. [Dataset]'], 'ubma_availibility': '1', 'id_number': '10.7801/87', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': "Weiland Lydia und Effelsberg Wolfgang und Ponzetto Simone Paolo (2014), Weakly supervised construction of a repository of iconic images"}
title: Data from the paper: Weakly supervised construction of a repository of iconic images
subject: 004 Computer science, internet
description: We present a first attempt at semi-automatically harvesting a dataset of iconic images. Iconic images are depicting objects or scenes, which arouse associations to abstract topics. Our method starts with representative topic-evoking images from Wikipedia, which are labeled with relevant concepts and entities found in their associated captions. These are used to query an online image repository (i.e., Flickr), in order to further acquire additional examples of topic-specific iconic relations. To this end, we leverage a combination of visual similarity measures, image clustering and matching algorithms to acquire clusters of iconic images that are topically connected to the original seed images, while also allowing for various degrees of diversity. Our first results are promising in that they indicate the feasibility of the task and that we are able to build a first version of our resource with minimal supervision.

[Dataset]']

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/121/', '10.7801/121'], 'title': 'Understanding the Impact of Social and Ambidextrous Knowing-in-practice on the Effective Use of Enterprise Systems', 'creator': 'Lauterbach, Jens', 'subject': '650 Management', 'description': 'When organizations want to gain benefits from Enterprise Systems, em-ployees not only need to use the technology, they need to use it effectively. However, very few studies have examined what it takes for employees to effectively use new IT. In this paper, we draw on the idea of knowing-in-practice and a recent conceptualization of effective use to propose and test a new model. Our findings suggest that our concepts of social an ambidextrous knowing can well explain the emergence of effective use af-ter an ES implementation. These findings give important insights on how employees embed learning of a new ES in their daily work practices to achieve effective use. This research can contribute to a better under-standing of how actual benefits from ES can be created. Nurturing capa-bilities for knowing and supporting employees’ in their work practices seems to be more important than competency-based training.', 'date': '2015-01', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'csv', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc0', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/121/1/Data_Survey_Effective_Use_CF_2015.xlsx', 'Lauterbach, Jens  (2015) Understanding the Impact of Social and Ambidextrous Knowing-in-practice on the Effective Use of Enterprise Systems.  [Dataset]'], 'ubma_language': 'ger', 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'Data can be received on received from the chair of Information Systems IV', 'id_number': '10.7801/121', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_project': 'BES-Coc |'}
title: Understanding the Impact of Social and Ambidextrous Knowing-in-practice on the Effective Use of Enterprise Systems
subject: 650 Management
description: When organizations want to gain benefits from Enterprise Systems, em-ployees not only need to use the technology, they need to use it effectively. However, very few studies have examined what it takes for employees to effectively use new IT. In this paper, we draw on the idea of knowing-in-practice and a recent conceptualization of effective use to propose and test a new model. Our findings suggest that our concepts of social an ambidextrous knowing can well explain the emergence of effective use af-ter an ES implementation. These findings give important insights on how employees embed learning of a new ES in their daily work practices to achieve effective use. This research can contribute to a better under-standing of how actual benefits from ES can be created. Nurturing capa-bilities for knowing and supporting employees’ in their work practices seems to be more important than competency-based training.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/121/1/Data_Survey_Effective_Use_CF_2015.xlsx', 'Lauterbach, Jens  (2015) Understanding the Impact of Social and Ambidextrous Knowing-in-practice on the Effective Use of Enterprise Systems.  [Dataset]']

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/127/', '10.7801/127'], 'title': 'Systematic Literature Review “Enterprise Systems Chartering” –Review Procedure and Analysis Results', 'creator': 'Berner, Martin', 'subject': '004 Computer science, internet', 'description': 'Our research follows a design science approach to develop a method that supports the initialization of ES implementation projects – the chartering phase. This project phase is highly relevant for implementation success, but is understudied in IS research. We conducted a systematic review of ES implementation literature in order to derive design principles for a chartering method. This paper contains data and the analysis results from this systematic literature review. The research activity is described in the paper “Design Principles for an Enterprise Systems Chartering Method” (Berner, Gansen & Maedche, 2015) presented at Tenth International Conference on Design Science Research in Information Systems and Technology (DESRIST 2015) in Dublin.', 'date': '2015-04-23', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'text', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc0', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/127/1/Chartering_DP_LIT.pdf', 'Berner, Martin  (2015) Systematic Literature Review “Enterprise Systems Chartering” –Review Procedure and Analysis Results.  [Dataset]'], 'ubma_language': 'eng', 'ubma_availibility': '1', 'ubma_availibility_free': 'public', 'id_number': '10.7801/127', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE'}
title: Systematic Literature Review “Enterprise Systems Chartering” –Review Procedure and Analysis Results
subject: 004 Computer science, internet
description: Our research follows a design science approach to develop a method that supports the initialization of ES implementation projects – the chartering phase. This project phase is highly relevant for implementation success, but is understudied in IS research. We conducted a systematic review of ES implementation literature in order to derive design principles for a chartering method. This paper contains data and the analysis results from this systematic literature review. The research activity is described in the paper “Design Principles for an Enterprise Systems Chartering Method” (Berner, Gansen & Maedche, 2015) presented at Tenth International Conference on Design Science Research in Information Systems and Technology (DESRIST 2015) in Dublin.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/', '10.7801/142'], 'title': 'Affect and the weight of idealistic and pragmatic concerns in decision situations', 'creator': 'Burger, Axel M.', 'subject': '150 Psychology', 'description': 'Individuals consider abstract values and principles important aspects of their identities. Nonetheless, they often make judgments and decisions that contradict these values and principles for the sake of pragmatic benefits. Assuming that the process of weighting idealistic and pragmatic concerns is context-sensitive, the present research argues that affect influences the relative weight of idealistic versus pragmatic concerns in decision situations due to its influence on the level of abstraction at which individuals represent situations mentally. Studies 1 and 2 demonstrate that more positive affect increases the prominent weighting of idealistic over pragmatic concerns while less positive affect leads to less differentiation between the relevance of idealistic and pragmatic concerns. Studies 3 and 4 test the assumption that affective influences on mental abstraction are crucial for affect-dependent shifts in the weighting of idealistic and pragmatic concerns. By bringing together theorizing on affect and cognition with recent theorizing on the role of mental abstraction for decision processes, this article highlights a mechanism through which decisions can be influenced by feelings that goes beyond the mechanisms that have typically been discussed in the affect and cognition literature so far.', 'date': '2015-08-26', 'type': ['Experiment', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['other', 'other', 'text', 'other', 'other', 'text', 'other', 'text', 'text', 'other', 'other', 'text', 'other', 'text', 'other'], 'language': ['en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en'], 'rights': ['no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/1/Study_1_Pretest_Rawdata.sav', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/2/Study_1a_Codebook.xls', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/3/Study_1a_Materials.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/4/Study_1a_Rawdata.sav', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/5/Study_1b_Codebook.xls', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/6/Study_1b_Materials.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/7/Study_1b_Rawdata.sav', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/8/Study_2_Materials_1.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/9/Study_2_Materials_2.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/10/Study_2_Rawdata.sav', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/11/Study_3_Codebook.xls', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/12/Study_3_Materials.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/13/Study_3_Rawdata.sav', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/14/Study_4_Materials.docx', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/142/15/Study_4_Rawdata.sav', 'Burger, Axel M.  (2015) Affect and the weight of idealistic and pragmatic concerns in decision situations.  [Experiment]'], 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'id_number': '10.7801/142', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE'}
title: Affect and the weight of idealistic and pragmatic concerns in decision situations
subject: 150 Psychology
description: Individuals consider abstract values and principles important aspects of their identities. Nonetheless, they often make judgments and decisions that contradict these values and principles for the sake of pragmatic benefits. Assuming that the process of weighting idealistic and pragmatic concerns is context-sensitive, the present research argues that affect influences the relative weight of idealistic versus pragmatic concerns in decision situations due to its influence on the level of abstraction at which individuals represent situations mentally. Studies 1 and 2 demonstrate that more positive affect increases the prominent weighting of idealistic over pragmatic concerns while less positive affect leads to less differentiation between the relevance of idealistic and pragmatic concerns. Studies 3 and 4 test the assumption that affective influences on mental abstraction are crucial for affect-dependent shifts in the weighting of idealistic and pragmatic concerns. By bringing together theorizing on affect and cognition with recent theorizing on the role of mental abstraction for decision processes, this article highlights a mechanism through which decisions can be influenced by feelings that goes beyond the mechanisms that have typically been discussed in the affect and cognition literature so far.

title: Kebir Ammi: Den Erinnerungslücken auf der Spur
subject: 840 French literature
description:
Lesung mit Kebir Ammi/Lecture avec Kebir Ammi

Von seiner Verlegerin erhält der Protagonist den Auftrag, ein Porträt des lateinischen Dichters Apuleius von Madaura (heutiges Algerien) anzufertigen, „le portrait d’un Algérien!“. Er hält dagegen „Algerien gab es doch damals noch gar nicht“. Doch seine Muse, wie er sie ironisch nennt, besteht darauf und für die Autorfigur beginnt ein literarisches Abenteuer. Die Reise führt den Erzähler über verschiedene geographische Stationen durch die Weltliteratur und schließlich nicht (nur) zu Apuleius, sondern der eigenen Schriftstellerrolle. Wie der Roman Apuleius, meine Verlegerin und ich (2006) vergegenwärtigen die Bücher von Kebir Ammi die Geschichte Nordafrikas – ihre antiken und kolonialen Bezüge ebenso wie jüdische und christliche – und rücken sie in ein neues Licht. Kebir Ammi hat sieben Romane publiziert (bei Gallimard u.a. sein Triptychon der Schwindler). In Deutschland ist der in Marokko geborene Autor, der in den USA studierte und in Paris lebt, gleichwohl erst noch zu entdecken.

Französische Woche Heidelberg-Mannheim 2015
Veranstalter: Universität Mannheim
Förderer: Deutsch-Französische-Vereinigung, Absolventum
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/155/1/Lesung%20Kebir%20Ammi%20Endversion.mp3', 'Gronemann, Claudia  (2015) Kebir Ammi: Den Erinnerungslücken auf der Spur.  [Speech]']
ubma_project:
Lesung und Gespräch in deutscher und französischer Sprache mit dem Autor Kebir Ammi

Moderation: Prof. Dr. Claudia Gronemann (Romanisches Seminar)

Übersetzungsprojekt mit Masterstudierenden des Romanischen Seminars unter Leitung von Claudia Gronemann in Zusammenarbeit mit Ines Bugert und Roselyne Versini-Waas

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/167/', '10.7801/167'], 'title': 'Data from the paper: Inhibition of Return in Fear of Spiders: Discrepant Eye Movement and Reaction Time Data', 'creator': ['Berdica, Elisa', 'Gerdes, Antje B. M.', 'Pittig, Andre', 'Alpers, Georg W.'], 'subject': '150 Psychology', 'description': 'Inhibition of return (IOR) refers to a bias against returning the attention to a previously attended location. As a foraging facilitator it is thought to facilitate systematic visual search. With respect to neutral stimuli, this is generally thought to be adaptive, but when threatening stimuli appear in our environment, such a bias may be maladaptive. This experiment investigated the influence of phobia-related stimuli on the IOR effect using a discrimination task. A sample of 50 students (25 high, 25 low in spider fear) completed an IOR task including schematic representations of spiders or butterflies as targets. Eye movements were recorded and to assess discrimination among targets, participants indicated with button presses if targets were spiders or butterflies. Reaction time data did not reveal a significant IOR effect but a significant interaction of group and target; spider fearful participants were faster to respond to spider targets than to butterflies. Furthermore, eye-tracking data showed a robust IOR effect independent of stimulus category. These results offer a more comprehensive assessment of the motor and oculomotor factors involved in the IOR effect.', 'date': '2014-07-03', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'archive', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'no_license', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/167/1/2Ex%20IOR%20Eyetracking.zip', 'Berdica, Elisa and Gerdes, Antje B. M. and Pittig, Andre and Alpers, Georg W. (2014) Data from the paper: Inhibition of Return in Fear of Spiders: Discrepant Eye Movement and Reaction Time Data. M. und Pittig, Andre und Alpers, Georg W. (2014), Inhibition of return under fear: Discrepant eye movement and reaction time data."}
title: Data from the paper: Inhibition of Return in Fear of Spiders: Discrepant Eye Movement and Reaction Time Data
creators: [{'creator_name': 'Berdica, Elisa', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Gerdes, Antje B. M.', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Pittig, Andre', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Alpers, Georg W.', 'name_identifier': ''}]
subject: 150 Psychology
description: Inhibition of return (IOR) refers to a bias against returning the attention to a previously attended location. As a foraging facilitator it is thought to facilitate systematic visual search. With respect to neutral stimuli, this is generally thought to be adaptive, but when threatening stimuli appear in our environment, such a bias may be maladaptive. This experiment investigated the influence of phobia-related stimuli on the IOR effect using a discrimination task. A sample of 50 students (25 high, 25 low in spider fear) completed an IOR task including schematic representations of spiders or butterflies as targets. Eye movements were recorded and to assess discrimination among targets, participants indicated with button presses if targets were spiders or butterflies. Reaction time data did not reveal a significant IOR effect but a significant interaction of group and target; spider fearful participants were faster to respond to spider targets than to butterflies. Furthermore, eye-tracking data showed a robust IOR effect independent of stimulus category. These results offer a more comprehensive assessment of the motor and oculomotor factors involved in the IOR effect.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/', '10.7801/182'], 'title': 'Data from the paper: A comprehensive look at phobic fear in inhibition of return: Phobia-related spiders as cues and targets', 'creator': ['Berdica, Elisa', 'Gerdes, Antje B. M.', 'Alpers, Georg W.'], 'subject': '150 Psychology', 'description': 'Background and objectives: The so called inhibition of return (IOR) effect refers to a bias against returning attention to a location which was previously investigated. Because emotionally salient material has the capacity to capture and hold attention it has been suggested that this material may disrupt this otherwise impressively stable phenomenon. Methods: 40 students participated in the experiment. Black and white schematic drawings of a spider, a butterfly or a cross were used as cues. A black dot, a spider, a butterfly or a cross were used as targets. Participants were required to press a key whenever the target picture appeared. Subsequently, they rated the pictures on valence and arousal. Results: Results showed that the IOR effect remained stable and did not diminish with either fear-related cues or fear-related targets. This data adds strong arguments for the stability of IOR. Limitations: The spider fearful participants were not diagnosed patients. They still meet the criteria for spider fear but follow-up studies should pursue the same question with a specific focus on participants’ levels of anxiety. Conclusions: This study is a contribution to the debate on how emotions affect or do not affect attentional processes such as the IOR. IOR appears to be a robust phenomenon and the emotional valence of neither the cue nor the emotional valence of the target can override it.', 'date': '2017', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['text', 'archive', 'archive', 'archive', 'archive', 'text'], 'language': ['en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en'], 'rights': ['cc_by', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/13/ReadMe.txt', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/14/Methods.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/3/Raw%20data.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/15/Analysis.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/5/Results.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/182/6/Berdica_Gerdes_Alpers_2017_A%20comprehensive%20look%20at%20phobic%20fear%20and%20IOR.pdf', 'Berdica, Elisa and Gerdes, Antje B. title: Data from the paper: A comprehensive look at phobic fear in inhibition of return: Phobia-related spiders as cues and targets
creators: [{'creator_name': 'Berdica, Elisa', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Gerdes, Antje B. M.', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Alpers, Georg W.', 'name_identifier': ''}]
subject: 150 Psychology
description: Background and objectives: The so called inhibition of return (IOR) effect refers to a bias against returning attention to a location which was previously investigated. Because emotionally salient material has the capacity to capture and hold attention it has been suggested that this material may disrupt this otherwise impressively stable phenomenon. Methods: 40 students participated in the experiment. Black and white schematic drawings of a spider, a butterfly or a cross were used as cues. A black dot, a spider, a butterfly or a cross were used as targets. Participants were required to press a key whenever the target picture appeared. Subsequently, they rated the pictures on valence and arousal. Results: Results showed that the IOR effect remained stable and did not diminish with either fear-related cues or fear-related targets. This data adds strong arguments for the stability of IOR. Limitations: The spider fearful participants were not diagnosed patients. They still meet the criteria for spider fear but follow-up studies should pursue the same question with a specific focus on participants’ levels of anxiety. Conclusions: This study is a contribution to the debate on how emotions affect or do not affect attentional processes such as the IOR. IOR appears to be a robust phenomenon and the emotional valence of neither the cue nor the emotional valence of the target can override it.

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/', '10.7801/183'], 'title': 'Data from the Master theses Hengen and Müller: Approaching feared stimuli: Behavioral, self-reported, and physiological changes after a spider approach task', 'creator': ['Hengen, Kristina M.', 'Müller, Bianca', 'Pittig, Andre', 'Alpers, Georg W.'], 'subject': '150 Psychology', 'description': 'Avoidance is one of the key symptoms of anxiety disorders and a contributing factor to their maintenance. Therefore, the reduction of avoidance behavior is a primary goal during exposure-based treatments. However, it is often difficult to motivate patients to start with exposure and there is a relatively high attrition rate. We modified a decision-making paradigm which we had previously established as a laboratory measure of avoidance tendencies in order to foster a self-selected approach. Spider fearful individuals (N = 50) were assigned to one of two conditions. Intervention group: individuals were differentially reinforced by hypothetical money for choosing a fear-relevant (spider picture) over a neutral stimulus (butterfly picture). Sham-control group: individuals were equally rewarded for selecting both stimuli. As expected, we observed a shift from avoidance to approach in the Intervention group but not in the Sham-control group. There were no group differences in self-reported fear of spiders, nor in arousal, fearfulness, and unpleasantness towards the fearful stimuli. Interestingly, the control compared to the Intervention group showed more electro dermal responses while looking at spider pictures. Outside of the test situation, there was no transfer of approaching behavior to a behavioral approach test (BAT) and no effects were found on psychophysiology in the BAT with a real spider. These findings suggest that incentives may be a useful tool to initiate self-selected exposure to aversive pictures but this may not be sufficient to change affective responses. Nevertheless, reinforcement may be an underused strategy to initiate effective treatment.', 'date': '2016-04', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['archive', 'archive', 'archive', 'archive', 'archive', 'archive'], 'language': ['en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en', 'en'], 'rights': ['cc_by', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license', 'no_license'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/1/Readme.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/5/Methoden.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/6/Rohdaten.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/3/Auswertung_Output.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/2/Ergebnisse.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/4/PDF.zip', 'Hengen, Kristina M. and Müller, Bianca and Pittig, Andre and Alpers, Georg W. title: Data from the Master theses Hengen and Müller: Approaching feared stimuli: Behavioral, self-reported, and physiological changes after a spider approach task
creators: [{'creator_name': 'Hengen, Kristina M.', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Müller, Bianca', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Pittig, Andre', 'name_identifier': ''}, {'creator_name': 'Alpers, Georg W.', 'name_identifier': ''}]
subject: 150 Psychology
description: Avoidance is one of the key symptoms of anxiety disorders and a contributing factor to their maintenance. Therefore, the reduction of avoidance behavior is a primary goal during exposure-based treatments. However, it is often difficult to motivate patients to start with exposure and there is a relatively high attrition rate. We modified a decision-making paradigm which we had previously established as a laboratory measure of avoidance tendencies in order to foster a self-selected approach. Spider fearful individuals (N = 50) were assigned to one of two conditions. Intervention group: individuals were differentially reinforced by hypothetical money for choosing a fear-relevant (spider picture) over a neutral stimulus (butterfly picture). Sham-control group: individuals were equally rewarded for selecting both stimuli. As expected, we observed a shift from avoidance to approach in the Intervention group but not in the Sham-control group. There were no group differences in self-reported fear of spiders, nor in arousal, fearfulness, and unpleasantness towards the fearful stimuli. Interestingly, the control compared to the Intervention group showed more electro dermal responses while looking at spider pictures. Outside of the test situation, there was no transfer of approaching behavior to a behavioral approach test (BAT) and no effects were found on psychophysiology in the BAT with a real spider. These findings suggest that incentives may be a useful tool to initiate self-selected exposure to aversive pictures but this may not be sufficient to change affective responses. Nevertheless, reinforcement may be an underused strategy to initiate effective treatment.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/1/Readme.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/5/Methoden.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/6/Rohdaten.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/3/Auswertung_Output.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/2/Ergebnisse.zip', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/183/4/PDF.zip', 'Hengen, Kristina M. and Müller, Bianca and Pittig, Andre and Alpers, Georg W. raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/189/', '10.7801/189'], 'title': 'Emotional Leadership of Open Source Development Teams: Examining Collaboration Structure and Collaboration Function', 'creator': ['Werder, Karl', 'Ashry, Mohamed'], 'subject': ['004 Computer science, internet', '650 Management'], 'description': 'Conceptual work on emotional contagion suggests the effect of emotional contagion from the team leader to the team members applies equally in the context of virtual teams that lack emotional cues based on physical presence, such as face-to-face interaction. Drawing on contagion theory and social network theory, we develop a model suggesting the effect of team leader emotional displays on team members’ emotional displays for positive and negative emotional displays. We suggest that the effect of team leader emotional displays depends on the team collaboration structure and team collaboration function. Using data from 999 open source projects, we test our hypotheses for positive and negative emotional displays jointly using seemingly unrelated regression. We find that the emotional contagion process applies to virtual teams. The results suggest a significant moderation effect for the team collaboration structure, unlike team collaboration function. More so, this interaction effect increases for higher levels of team collaboration structure and both, positive and negative emotional displays. The implications for research and practice show the importance of collaboration structure for the conformance and convergence of team emotions.', 'date': '2016-08-05', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': 'csv', 'language': 'en', 'rights': 'cc0', 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/189/1/Full_data_set.csv', 'Werder, Karl and Ashry, Mohamed  (2016) Emotional Leadership of Open Source Development Teams: Examining Collaboration Structure and Collaboration Function.  [Dataset]'], 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'id_number': '10.7801/189', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE'}
title: Emotional Leadership of Open Source Development Teams: Examining Collaboration Structure and Collaboration Function
subject: ['004 Computer science, internet', '650 Management']
description: Conceptual work on emotional contagion suggests the effect of emotional contagion from the team leader to the team members applies equally in the context of virtual teams that lack emotional cues based on physical presence, such as face-to-face interaction. Drawing on contagion theory and social network theory, we develop a model suggesting the effect of team leader emotional displays on team members’ emotional displays for positive and negative emotional displays. We suggest that the effect of team leader emotional displays depends on the team collaboration structure and team collaboration function. Using data from 999 open source projects, we test our hypotheses for positive and negative emotional displays jointly using seemingly unrelated regression. We find that the emotional contagion process applies to virtual teams. The results suggest a significant moderation effect for the team collaboration structure, unlike team collaboration function. More so, this interaction effect increases for higher levels of team collaboration structure and both, positive and negative emotional displays. The implications for research and practice show the importance of collaboration structure for the conformance and convergence of team emotions.
identifier: ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/189/1/Full_data_set.csv', 'Werder, Karl and Ashry, Mohamed  (2016) Emotional Leadership of Open Source Development Teams: Examining Collaboration Structure and Collaboration Function.  [Dataset]']

raw_metadata: {'relation': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/193/', '10.7801/193'], 'title': 'Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2016 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten', 'creator': ['Auberer, Benjamin', 'Kaiser, Jessica', 'Leichtweiß, Angela'], 'subject': '020 Library and information sciences', 'description': 'Unter dem Motto ‚Sagen Sie uns Ihre Meinung‘ führte die Universitätsbibliothek vom 17. bis 30. Oktober 2016 eine Online-Benutzerumfrage durch. Der Fragebogen wurde mit der Software Limesurvey erstellt und war über das Internet frei zugänglich in deutscher und englischer Sprache. Um möglichst viele Angehörige der Universität und sonstige Nutzergruppen zu erreichen, wurde die Umfrage über alle von der UB Mannheim genutzten Kanäle breit beworben: z.B. über Plakate, die Rektoratsnachrichten, die eigene Homepage, Twitter, den Facebook-Auftritt der UB und Universität und über E-Mail an alle Studierenden und die zentralen Einrichtungen der Universität. Die Befragten konnten an einem Gewinnspiel teilnehmen und verschiedene Preise gewinnen. Der Fragebogen ist als PDF-Datei hinterlegt, aus der auch kontextabhängige Fragen ersichtlich werden. Der Antwortdatensatz ist als CSV-Datei hinterlegt, freie Kommentare wurden eingeschränkt zugänglich gemacht. Vollständig abgeschlossen wurde der Fragebogen von 1.420 Nutzern. Ausgewertet wurde die Gesamtzahl von 2.008 zumindest teilweise ausgefüllten Fragebögen.', 'date': '2017-04-20', 'type': ['Dataset', 'NonPeerReviewed'], 'format': ['text', 'text', 'csv', 'csv'], 'language': ['en', 'en', 'en', 'en'], 'rights': ['cc0', 'cc0', 'cc0', 'cc0'], 'identifier': ['https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/193/1/Benutzerumfrage_2016_UBMannheim_Fragebogen_deutsch.pdf', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/193/2/Benutzerumfrage_2016_UBMannheim_Fragebogen_englisch.pdf', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/193/3/Benutzerumfrage_2016_UBMannheim.csv', 'https://madata.bib.uni-mannheim.de/193/4/Benutzerumfrage_2016_UBMannheim_kommentare.csv', 'Auberer, Benjamin and Kaiser, Jessica and Leichtweiß, Angela (2017) Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2016 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten. [Dataset]'], 'ubma_additional_title': 'Survey of the Mannheim University Library 2016 - questionnaire and results', 'ubma_availibility': '2', 'id_number': '10.7801/193', 'ubma_id_number_checked': 'TRUE', 'ubma_publications': "Auberer Benjamin und Klein Annette und Kaiser Jessica und Leichtweiß Angela (2017), Abschlussbericht zur Umfrage an der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2016"}
title: Benutzerumfrage der Universitätsbibliothek Mannheim 2016 - Fragebogen und Antwortdaten
subject: 020 Library and information sciences
description: Unter dem Motto ‚Sagen Sie uns Ihre Meinung‘ führte die Universitätsbibliothek vom 17. bis 30. Oktober 2016 eine Online-Benutzerumfrage durch. Der Fragebogen wurde mit der Software Limesurvey erstellt und war über das Internet frei zugänglich in deutscher und englischer Sprache. Um möglichst viele Angehörige der Universität und sonstige Nutzergruppen zu erreichen, wurde die Umfrage über alle von der UB Mannheim genutzten Kanäle breit beworben: z.B. über Plakate, die Rektoratsnachrichten, die eigene Homepage, Twitter, den Facebook-Auftritt der UB und Universität und über E-Mail an alle Studierenden und die zentralen Einrichtungen der Universität. Die Befragten konnten an einem Gewinnspiel teilnehmen und verschiedene Preise gewinnen. Der Fragebogen ist als PDF-Datei hinterlegt, aus der auch kontextabhängige Fragen ersichtlich werden. Der Antwortdatensatz ist als CSV-Datei hinterlegt, freie Kommentare wurden eingeschränkt zugänglich gemacht. Vollständig abgeschlossen wurde der Fragebogen von 1.420 Nutzern. Ausgewertet wurde die Gesamtzahl von 2.008 zumindest teilweise ausgefüllten Fragebögen.

title: Web Data Commons - RDFa, Microdata, and Microformat October 2016 Data Set
subject: 004 Computer science, internet
description: Microformat, Microdata and RDFa data from the October 2016 Common Crawl web corpus. We found structured data within 1.24 billion HTML pages out of the 3.2 billion pages contained in the crawl (38%). These pages originate from 5.63 million different pay-level-domains out of the 34 million pay-level-domains covered by the crawl (16.5%). Altogether, the extracted data sets consist of 44.2 billion RDF quads.
